review.title: Knowledge, Justification, and Reason-Based Belief
review.abstract: Is knowledge definable as justified true belief ("JTB")? We argue that one can legitimately answer positively or negatively, depending on how the notion of justification is understood. To facilitate our argument, we introduce a simple propositional logic of reason-based belief. We show that this logic is sufficiently flexible to accommodate various useful features, including quantification over reasons. We use our framework to contrast two notions of JTB: one internalist, the other externalist. We argue that Gettier cases essentially challenge the internalist notion but not the externalist one. In particular, we may equate knowledge and JTB if the latter is grounded in what we call "adequate" reasons.

sections.heading: 2 A Simple Logic of Reason-Based Belief
sections.text: We distinguish between two types of reasons: those that merely "support" a proposal by inclining an agent to believe in it, and those that not only support a proposal but are "adequate" themselves. Our analysis of the Gettier cases depends on a precise understanding of this central distinction. Accordingly, our task in this section is to introduce a simple theory of reason-based belief in which we formalize this distinction. An important caveat is that we are not trying to break down the concept of "adequate reason" into more fundamental concepts. For example, one might wish to analyze appropriateness in terms of reliability, counterfactual sensitivity, or other concepts. We consciously avoid such examples. This has some similarities to the work in [4, 5] but our logic is much simpler and we use it as part of a different analysis.

sections.heading: 3 Justified True Belief and Knowledge
sections.text: We use our logical framework to distinguish between two notions of righteous, true faith (henceforth "JTB"): the first is an internalist notion that Gettier called insufficient for knowledge; the second is an externalist notion that we claim to be immune to Gettier scenarios. Once we have defined these two notions of JTB, we show their relationship and discuss whether external JTB could be a viable candidate for knowledge.
